data.Name: ConventionalCore
data.Description:
A whole, slabbed or preserved recovered cylindrical sample of rock. Conventional cores are typically 2.375 to 5.5 inch [6 to 14 cm] in diameter and cut in 6 or 9 metre barrel lengths. The sample length (see RockSample data.SampleLength) and diameter (see RockSample data.SampleDiameter) should be captured if possible. The IsCoreSlabbed flag and sample preservation status (see RockSample data.PreservationTypeID) should be completed if applicable. 
If a Coring record is related to this rock sample, the related Coring must be of type ConventionalCoring.

data.Name: ConventionalCore.Chip
data.Description:
Small fragments of rock chips or pieces broken from a conventional core sample (see ConventionalCore). The sample interval (see RockSample data.SampleInterval) and weight (see RockSample data.SampleWeight) should be captured if possible.
If a Coring record is related to this rock sample, the related Coring must be of type ConventionalCoring.

data.Name: ConventionalCore.Crushed
data.Description:
Crushed rock taken from a conventional core sample (see ConventionalCore). The sample interval (see RockSample data.SampleInterval) and weight (see RockSample data.SampleWeight) should be captured if possible. Crushed samples can be generated to various levels of granularity and are commonly used for particle size analysis, geochemistry, fluid typing or clay typing.
If a Coring record is related to this rock sample, the related Coring must be of type ConventionalCoring.

data.Name: CorePlug
data.Description:
A small cylindrical rock sample cut or drilled from a conventional core (see ConventionalCore). Core plugs are typically, but not limited to 1 to 1-1/2 inch [2.5 to 3.8 cm] in diameter and 1 to 2 inch. [2.5 to 5 cm] in length. The core plug orientation (see RockSample data.SampleOrientationID), length (see RockSample data.SampleLength) and diameter (see RockSample data.SampleDiameter) should be captured if possible. If analyzed complete the RockSample data.IsPlugCleaned flag.
Core plugs are typically packaged to prevent grain loss in nickel foil, aluminium foil, teflon tape with stainless steel screens. 
If a Coring record is related to this rock sample, the related Coring must be of type ConventionalCoring.

data.Name: CorePlug.MicroPlug
data.Description:
A small cylindrical rock sample cut or drilled from the core plug sample (see CorePlug). Micro plugs are typically 1 to 3mm in diameter and 20mm in length and used for micro CT measurements. The plug orientation (see RockSample data.SampleOrientationID), length (see RockSample data.SampleLength) and diameter (see RockSample data.SampleDiameter) should be captured if possible.
If a Coring record is related to this rock sample, the related Coring must be of type ConventionalCoring.

data.Name: CorePlug.Trim
data.Description:
A small portion of rock cut from a core plug sample (see CorePlug). Trims are typically used for generating slides, destructive testing, or analysis that doesn't require a regularly shaped sample. Also known as a offcut or a slice. The sample weight (see RockSample data.SampleWeight) should be captured if possible.
If a Coring record is related to this rock sample, the related Coring must be of type ConventionalCoring.

data.Name: Cuttings
data.Description:
Small pieces of rock broken away due to the action of the bit teeth during drilling. Cuttings can be washed and dried, unwashed (see RockSample data.AreCuttingsWashedAndDried flag) and collected in trays for lithological descriptions (see Cuttings.SampleTray). The cuttings interval (see RockSample data.SampleInterval) and weight (see RockSample data.SampleWeight) should be captured if possible.
Cuttings are screened out of the liquid mud system at the  shakers and are monitored for composition, size, shape, color, texture, hydrocarbon content and other properties by the mud engineer at the rig site.

data.Name: Cuttings.Crushed
data.Description: Crushed rock taken from cutting samples (see Cuttings). The sample interval (see RockSample data.SampleInterval) and weight (see RockSample data.SampleWeight) should be captured if possible. Depending upon the purpose of the sample, crushed cuttings may be from either washed and dried or unwashed samples. Samples are commonly used for particle size analysis, geochemistry, fluid typing or clay typing.

data.Name: Cuttings.SampleTray
data.Description: Cutting samples (see Cuttings) that are specially collected in a tray and typically used for lithology and hydrocarbon fluorescence descriptions.

data.Name: SidewallCore
data.Description:
A cylindrical sample of rock taken from the side of the borehole, usually by a wireline tool. Sidewall cores may be taken using percussion or mechanical methods (see SidewallCoreType).  The sample length (see RockSample data.SampleLength) and diameter (see RockSample data.SampleDiameter) should be captured if possible. Sample preservation status (see RockSample data.PreservationTypeID) should be completed if applicable. 
If a Coring record is related to this rock sample, the related Coring must be of type SidewallCoring

data.Name: SidewallCore.Crushed
data.Description:
Crushed rock taken from a Sidewall Core sample (see SidewallCore).  The sample interval (see RockSample data.SampleInterval) and weight (see RockSample data.SampleWeight) should be captured if possible. Crushed samples can be generated to various levels of granularity, and is commonly used for particle size analysis, geochemistry, fluid typing or clay typing.
If a Coring record is related to this rock sample, the related Coring must be of type SidewallCoring.

data.Name: SidewallCore.Trim
data.Description:
A portion of rock cut from a Sidewall Core sample (see SidewallCore) and typically used for generating slides, destructive testing, or analysis that doesn't require a regularly shaped sample. Also known as an offcut or a slice. The sample weight (see RockSample data.SampleWeight) should be captured if possible.
If a Coring record is related to this rock sample, the related Coring must be of type SidewallCoring.

data.Name: Slide.Palaeontological
data.Description: Slide sample prepared for paleontological studies from a biostrat sample. Prepared to evaluate the fauna.

data.Name: Slide.Palynological
data.Description: Slide sample prepared for palynological studies from a biostrat sample. Prepared to evaluate the flora.

data.Name: Slide.PolishedSection
data.Description: Slide sample prepared as a polished section for Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM).

data.Name: Slide.ThinSection
data.Description: Optically transparent flat slivers of rock mounted on a microscope slide for analysis.

data.Name: Outcrop
data.Description: A sample taken from an outcrop. The sample length (see RockSample data.SampleLength), diameter (see RockSample data.SampleDiameter), weight (see RockSample data.SampleWeight) and sample preservation status (see RockSample data.PreservationTypeID) should be captured if applicable. Outcrop will have a surface location instead of wellbore.

data.Name: Slide
data.Description: Rock sample fixed to a glass slide to view under a microscope.

data.Name: Crushed
data.Description: Sample of crushed rock from an unidentified sample. This reference value is only to be used when the parent rock sample type (Conventional vs Sidewall vs Cuttings, e.g.) is unknown. If it is known, use the other appropriate reference value.

data.Name: ConventionalCore.SlabPreservation
data.Description: Wholebore core is cut lengthwise. This is commonly 1/3 and 2/3 split, but this proportion may vary. SlabPreservation identifies the piece intended for preservation and viewing as opposed to further sub-sampling (although rarely it may also be sub-sampled). When slabbing produces a smaller and larger piece, SlabPreservation refers to the smaller piece.

data.Name: ConventionalCore.SlabWorking
data.Description: Wholebore core is cut lengthwise. This is commonly 1/3 and 2/3 split, but this proportion may vary. SlabWorking identifies the piece intended for sub-sampling to common shapes for additional lab measurements. When slabbing produces a smaller and larger piece, SlabWorking refers to the larger piece.

data.Name: Trim
data.Description: Sample of a plug end trim from an unidentified sample. This reference value is only to be used when the parent rock sample type (Conventional vs Sidewall, e.g.) is unknown. If it is known, use the other appropriate reference value.

data.Name: Plug
data.Description: Sample of a plug from an unidentified sample. This reference value is only to be used when the parent rock sample type (Conventional vs Sidewall, e.g.) is unknown. If it is known, use the other appropriate reference value.

data.Name: Chip
data.Description: Sample of a chip from an unidentified sample. This reference value is only to be used when the parent rock sample type (Conventional vs Sidewall, e.g.) is unknown. If it is known, use the other appropriate reference value.

data.Name: MicroPlug
data.Description: Sample of a microplug from an unidentified sample. This reference value is only to be used when the parent rock sample type (Conventional vs Sidewall, e.g.) is unknown. If it is known, use the other appropriate reference value.
